we at MIT and locals welcome you Judith thank you for coming Judith has been an
outstanding feminist Voyer media productionist
sounding board Evangelical media artist and participant writer bookmaker
traveler and architect I can't say enough good things about the input that Judith has given me
personally over my own artistic career born in Columbus Ohio she's been
everywhere in fact I usually see Judith in far-flung cities not where she lives
echo in the shadow of the city Vampira is an exod ition piece that I
saw many years ago and I'm always reminded of even in my current production it's also true that many of
the things Judith has said over the years appears in the writings of others later and I'm
surprised but somehow we all remember Judith when she first
said when she talked about the interactivity as a primal ingredient of
art production and spatial construction and identity so with no further Ado I'd like to
welcome uh Judith thank you for
coming hi um well I want to thank Julia for that great introduction and also thank Cavs Lissa and Meg for having me
here as a senior fellow can you hear me yeah
okay I can't turn off the lights oh um not yet just a second um you'll have
plenty of chance to sit in the dark um what I'm going to do tonight is to just
give you an overview of my work as an artist as juliia mentioned I've been
working for a really long time and I have a lot of different projects so what I decided to do for tonight is excerpt
from a number of types of Works rather than giving you much of an overview
about any kind of work and I think for those of you who are students in the audience
it's always really good to know what people's day jobs are and have been how they've developed through different
moments in their career because I think that's the kind of thing that often you want to take away from one of these
sorts of talks so I will be mentioning those things when I when I'm talking I
began as an architect and now now you can turn off the lights
um I began as an architect and um lucky for me but you know probably not so so
lucky if you're pursuing an architecture career when I was first out of architecture school I got a job at
Skidmore Owings and Marl and almost immediately was laid off and that
propelled me back into school and this I'm I'm talking about 1977 or so and I went back to school at
the San Francisco art institute and also began taking classes in University of California at Berkeley in the rhetoric
Department which just happened to be the place where all of postmodernity and postmodern thinking was funneling
through the United States through people like uh Jean France leotar through Raymond bour through chrisan Mets
through dareda uh Fuko etc etc and it was completely an accident and completely by
chance that I happened to be there at that time but being there at that time in San Francisco really
framed um my thinking and the kind of work that I was doing and one of the
first kinds of work that I started doing was performance art because when I was going to art school this again this is
1977 everybody in art school was a performance artist and Joan was one of
the most famous performance artists of all and one of the few women who were actually working in performance art and
I remember seeing your performance at aing lton Street I think in 1976 I don't
know if you remember that but I but I remember because it was a very compelling moment so I became interested
in performance art and I also saw performance and the performative as a way of presenting certain kinds of ideas
and at this particular time in performance art it was transitioning out
of performance using the body or about the body so particularly into other
forms of media because we're at the end of the 1970s when questions around video
and how video is being used in the art world first come into play and so what you're looking at here is my actual very
first performance and it was done at aing Lon Street in 1978 I believe and what I did trying to
make use of my architecture because I I've never wanted to give anything up or let anything go is I built out this room
at aing lton Street in such a way that it housed a 2,000 pound or 2000 yeah
2,000 PB trough of sand that went horizontally across the room and the
screen that you see are projecting stories called from women's lives it was
a time when questions about identity and the performative in terms of identity
for those of you familiar with Judith Butler it's it's the notion that we all perform our identities differently and
construct them differently every day so on these three screens I had all of these different stories of women's lives
and then in front of that I was performing using a piece of wire mesh and I was turning that wire mesh MH into
different sculptures almost like sculptural gesture drawings using them you know one minute setups with a pose
another one minute setup with a pose etc etc for about 20 minutes until at one
point after about 10 minutes this is backwards but I hung up this the um
screen and made a hammock out of it and then at a certain point in the performance I pulled the screen thread
that held the sand in place and all the sand dumped down on me and that's kind of Midway through the
performance and that's the end and then in True Performance fashion because Al
also these things you know they're events and they were one night only and so about the last thing you wanted to do this took two weeks to build about the
last thing you want to do is clean it up so I left it up for a week or so until the next performance artist came in and
transformed the space and so this became known as a performance installation and I think I think you did that with your
work to too then too but you know the whole idea of performance installation
which the art world seems to think just happened a year ago is has been around for a very long time at any rate um this
performance led to several other performances where I also was exploring questions of media and I'm not going to
go into them in very great detail but I did one that took place over two weeks
at the San Francisco art institute in a show called motion the women's performance Collective
and it basically dealt with soap oper themes in particular the pleasure associated with performing as an evil
character and in this particular case it was sort of scenes from a relationship um and I would change the
order of eight scenes over the course of this twoe period so it was very you know soap opera derived and these are just
some shots of it and the audience for this was located in the center and the performance took place all around them
and I used a lot of slides and video and and stuff like that um this is another
shot from it where people are sleeping but they're sleeping against the wall um ultimately this became a video and
similarly in another space llama Mel I did another performance called cup couch
which explored the relationship between metaphor and M
metomic again I was trying to apply what I was learning in graduate school to questions around the performative and
again the audience was situated in the center of the room and the media took place all around and I'm also just
mentioning this just to remind people that media and art have been around for a very long time at any rate what
happened to me in terms of performance was that it was pretty clear to me by the end of the
1980s that I wasn't going to be able to be a performance orst because it was kind of over in the sense of of getting
people to fund things or or even having people um invite me to do things I kind
of had missed that particular moment in the art world and the art world I think is is and Julia and Joan and Joe and
other people may disagree with me but I think the art world is very periodized by what it will support and what it
won't support So as a young artist and you know trying to get out of school I immediately switched into making
videotapes and um while I was making that switch and also trying to come to
terms with my interest in film Theory what became known as academic feminism
and also questions about architecture that that were still circulating in my
uh thinking I started to make videotapes but meanwhile I also had to have a job
one of those horrible things um and so my job after I got laid off was to
design party spaces for big corporations and what you're looking at is San Francisco it in the 1980s excuse me and
it it's an old hanger or kind of warehouse space that coca colola took over and that went from this
space to this space and little did I know as an extremely young person that
it would be the biggest budget I ever had because you think oh this will just continue forever um and of course it
didn't um but this this space was built to to become a party space for a 2hour
party that Coca-Cola was having for its bottlers in San Francisco and for those
of you who are architecture architecture trained if you decoded this you would see that I was very very influenced by
the work of um Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi in particular they were my very big heroes in architecture
school and I was particularly affected by learning from Las Vegas because I decided that how I would manage this
space which was basically a corridor with food was I would make this um series of of uh kind of disney-esque
eating huts and you would be able to eat your way through the ethnic history of San Francisco and so this is pretty much
um all that cocacola agreed to however because I was in school and because I
was extremely naive and and perhaps it was a good thing I was also trying to to
have an effect on the corporate world and so I kept proposing well why don't we do something that's more historically
accurate about what happened when Coca-Cola gained hemony worldwide and so these are some drawings I made about
when Coca-Cola came to Japan and the Coca-Cola dispenser replaces the refrigerator I mean they were meant to
be also humorous I thought I could use irony and humor in the corporate world more successfully than I was able to
do this is China where um the changing room has a Coca-Cola dispenser next to
it and this is the only one that they did do which unfortunately I don't have any shots of but the one thing that they
did go for was just was a Hut basically made out of recycled Coca-Cola cans that
would allow us also to dump garbage because at a party with 4,000 people in 2 hours and they're only allowed to
drink Coke there's no place for garbage and nobody wanted to have garbage cans around and that kind of thing and so we
made a moat and made the Hut out of recycled Coca-Cola cans and we featured
avocado and sprouts and all of this stuff we're in 1980 now we featured all of this and that was of new to the
people who were attending the party because they were mostly from the Midwest so um this project I published
quite a bit because also in architecture as those of you in architecture know in
architecture we have a long tradition of publishing and that's Al often been
negatively viewed as paper architecture however in the art World Young Artists tend not to publish nearly as much and
for me this project was quite useful because I published it so much that finally curators saw it and that did lead to to
further projects I'm going to show you um two more architecture projects and I should also mention that for me when I
was in architecture school I was thinking about how or what is architecture and I think that question
is still very much um both needs to be asked in architecture and very much is
asked in most architecture programs as and I I know it's asked here at MIT and
when I decided architecture was for me was actually the representation in built space of our
social relations and you can see in that formulation some of the traces of my
history or my interest at the time which were Marxism questions about feminism
questions about social relations questions about how people use space and
also how all of these codes or these uh different forms of conceiving space
actually impact the built world and I've pretty much even today still refer to
that Trope when I'm thinking about architecture Visa V space at any rate in 1980 after um the
Coca-Cola piece Lyn hman who's a very well-known artist from San Francisco had
a museum that she called The Floating Museum and it was an alternative space essentially with no permanent space and
she asked me to do a project at a shopping mall that was going out of business in Silicon Valley
and this shopping mall didn't have a um a nean Marcus it had a pennies and the
owner of the shopping mall thought if we only could bring High art here maybe the rich people would shop here it was as
you can imagine a pretty silly idea but nonetheless for me it was a great launching pad to do a project and again
I referred a lot to the work of Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi in the parking lot I proposed
that we make an alternative kind of Museum out of the shopping mall and I
called it display Museum of signs and in the windows I wanted to have a kind of changing Panorama of what this Museum
would be and it was kind of up to the shopkeepers to to make those decisions I was also basing this very much on
Notions about the memory Theater which I was very interested in at the time and continueed to be interested in which is
a way of reading images and inputting architecture into your mind in order to
remember things as well as a way of encoding information and so I used this
concept of the memory theater in conceiving of um of this Museum and if
you wanted to read about that Francis Yates is still the best um person and her book is called the art of memory
anyway at the at the center of this um shopping mall I located the map and this
is you know very typical of a California shopping mall and this was a map that would describe how the museum worked and
functioned what you could do in this Museum and again you know this was totally meant as an imaginary construct
and additionally I was playing with all kinds of things that had to do with questions about Marxism and
psychoanalysis such as trying to get the shop owners to collaborate on the construction of their displays instead
of competing setting up things within the shop so that you would actually have
um strange Notions about what you desired and what you didn't desire and why and so it was kind of a treasure
hunt and in the center is kind of where I located the main part of this you can also see that this was a very expensive
project because it would have cost them a lot of money to actually go to all the trouble of Designing and building
building all these things and then the final thing I wanted to do with the project was to make a labeling Center so
you could so the the entire or at least one store would be under deconstruction
Allah Dara and so you know this is you know many ways a graduate project but still it it um was very important to me
and it fueled a lot of different research projects and of course like all of these sorts of projects it was not
done surprise um but what I decided to do remember I'm the person who doesn't like to lose anything was I decided to
write an article about it which I called casual imagination and I also
made a videotape because I had spent so much time in the shopping mall making
friends with all these people and doing all these studies that I decided Well how can I make use of this contact and
how can I make something out of this so I made a single Channel video called casual Shopper which um you can go ahead
and put that in well actually let me just set it up first because I'm I'm going to try not to talk over my work
which is something new for me um but what the video was about was it took off
from a very important article that was written by Laura mvy in 1975 it was called visual pleasure and
narrative Cinema and in that article she's writing as a feminist and also as a film theoretician she's asking the
question how come in mainstream film when the woman comes on the screen the
action stops there's a kiss an interlude or something but virtually nothing happens
then the kiss is over and the narrative resumes and something happens etc etc so I thought what would happen if I made a
film where when the woman came on the screen something happened and when the man came
on he disappeared and so that's really the kind of logic that underscores this film and I decided to make it about
shopping because shopping is such an interesting Trope of 20th century culture and it has such a long history
if you think about Walter Benjamine and the Flor I thought about this female character as a kind of fluse so you can
you can start it and this is about about a 7 minute clip from this

and so there was about four or five years where it was actually fun and you could try lots of

I made a lot of music videos and um they that also became increasingly
corporatized and even more exploitative of artists labor than the art world was
so around 198 two when I was beginning to do all these music videos and also
making all these single Channel vide tapes I started to think about the coming back more into the art world as
an artist and for me it was a a moment of Crisis because I was very
dissatisfied with the viewing conventions that I mentioned and also increasingly even in
1982 dissatisfied with a world of popular culture since it wasn't really turning out as I had hoped so I began to
think about what my I do that would combine all of my interests I was interested in performance I was still
interested in architecture I had half of a PhD from UC Berkeley and film Theory
feminism and other madeup things which I knew would be useless in terms of actually getting a job so I thought H
the art world that doesn't look so bad and actually I think the art world is a place still where you can try things out
and experiment and there aren't that many other places in in US culture anywhere where that's possible possible
so I began to propose um actuallyy you should put in tape number four I began
to propose this VD this um video installation film um installation called
in the shadow of the city Vampira that Julia was mentioning in her introduction
and I tried to combine all of my interests in one project and soon as it
comes on um I will um tell you about it um it
was a very simple very low Tech project it used two slides on each side of a
screen that bisected a room and in those two slides which dissolved continuously I projected two
film loops and I made the space here you can see the setup and those are the film
loops and the little proje projections and then the slides are in the back and I made it so that you could see the
whole thing in a minute because obviously one of the problems of viewing
video in a gallery is that no one is going to come and spend a half an hour they really want a quick hit and at the
time in the art world what was around was a lot of painting and by the way this is not yellow it's um actually kind
of pink um at any rate so I wanted to make something that you could actually see get in and out in maybe 15 seconds
if that's all you all you wanted to spend and actually have some idea of what you were
seeing and so that was sort of the brief in terms of like an architectural brief
of what I was trying to do the subject matter came from my reading of Jean Louie bodri AR's notion of the kind of
subjectivity that you and I and everyone performs when they're in front of the
television set and in his reading which is very very pessimistic we all become
schizophrenics in front of the screen and so I decided in the title using the
notion of them vampire the vampire to propose another way of understanding our
insatiable hunger for images and that's with a vampire and so I kind of wrote
this um I I thought it was funny anyway article about this vampiric subject who
has a sensationable hunger for images and who consumes images at of acious
pace and and wanders the city etc etc um and so that became the title of the
piece and how the piece actually functioned is that because when you look
at a Hollywood film you're used to getting something called narrative closure in other words you look for the
beginning and the middle and the end in the film how this piece functioned was
that you watched it and watched the different slides changing in relationship to the film Loops all the
while looking for this narrative closure and what would actually happen to you as a viewer as you wandered around was that
you would actually never get this narrative closure but it would excite your desire for it and so this piece
sort of kept you circling around it in this as a kind of anxious form of
subjectivity um can you stop the tape for a second and then what I'm going to do now is um so that was my big
breakthrough piece for me I mean it um doesn't seem like that much when you you know when I talk about it but for me it
was a very big deal because I had solved some of these problems that I was trying to solve the other thing that I really
wanted to do at this point in in uh in the art world was I really wanted to use
the art world to explore issues that I was interested in so by this time I had
already decided something else which as an artist is not the best solution to
make but it was the one that I made at the time and that was not to have a signature style so that each of my
projects comes out of a research methodology meaning I'll have an idea
about something I'm interested in exploring and then both the form and the content come from that and obviously in
an art World which has become increasingly corporate and we're in the kind of height of a corporate art world
right now at least in New York City this doesn't necessarily serve you very well as an artist but it has let me have a
fairly interesting practice as an artist because it's let me follow my own interests and go where they take me
rather than having to make product or the same thing so the collector can can show his friend and say oh I have one of
those oh I have one of those so but I wouldn't I have to say and if somebody wants to ask me
about this we can talk about this later I wouldn't necessarily recommend this as a solution it's just what I did um not
that it's not too late um it's never too late to change but anyway so the the projects that I'm going to show you now
very very quickly in video form are different experiments that take up different issues and for each one I
generally as I said do research I often write an article or two which I publish
and then I do the artwork and the artwork may have several different parameters like it may be film or video
it might be a book it might be an an architecture installation or an

lot of exhibition designs as an art arti so if you ever see my CV you'll see a

had crossed that imaginary divide between the Artist as artist and the
museum side of the Artist as curator or exhibition designer but nonetheless I
